IMPRECISE TERMINOLOGY: "ultrametric rigidity" is not a standard mathematical term.

The phrase "the ultrametric rigidity of N" is informal and undefined. The ultrametric inequality N(x+y) <= max(N(x), N(y)) is a specific axiom. The isosceles property (N(x+y) = max(N(x), N(y)) when N(x) != N(y)) is a theorem. The discreteness of the value group |k*| for a local field is a property of k, not of N. "Rigidity" could refer to any of these, or to the broader phenomenon that ultrametric norms on finite-dimensional spaces are more constrained than archimedean ones.

A precise statement should specify which property of non-archimedean norms is being invoked, e.g., "the ultrametric inequality N(x+y) <= max(N(x), N(y))" or "the isosceles property of ultrametric norms".
